dans_19 wrote:

> I have an EJB that is creating some DAO objects through a factory
> class. I want to test my EJB through Junit. But the DAO classes have
> not been fully implemented yet. I want to test the EJB in a way that
> the tests be independent of DAO classes implementation. The DAO
> classes are returning DTO's to the EJB. Can this be done in any way.

To test an EJB, you can instantiate the bean class directly and use it 
like a normal Java class. To do this, you usually have to "work around" 
any JNDI lookups the EJB makes and you often have to simulate the 
EJBContext somehow. Details in _JUnit Recipes_, Chapter 11.

It looks like you want to invoke your EJB, passing it something that 
"looks like" a DAO class, without it being the real thing. Extract an 
interface from the DAO class and add a way to inject a DAO interface 
into your EJB. It can be as simple as adding a method like this:

public void setDao(IMyDao myDao) {
     this.myDao = myDao;
}

and invoking it only from the tests. When your EJB needs to use its 
myDao field, it lazily instantiates a DAO class as long as you haven't 
already given it a DAO interface object.

Those should be all the pieces you need.
